title: Donald Trump to face impeachment inquiry over Ukraine whistleblower allegations, Nancy Pelosi announces
text:
Nancy Pelosi making her historic announcement - REX More

The Democrats last night announced they will begin impeachment proceedings against Donald Trump, making him only the fourth US president in history to face the move.

In an historic press conference, Nancy Pelosi, the most senior Democrat in the House of Representatives, said that it was time to move ahead with an impeachment inquiry.

She said the trigger was claims that Mr Trump held back aid to Ukraine in the hope its leader would investigate Joe Biden, the former US vice president who is seeking the White House in 2020.

The US president had tried to head off the move at the last minute, promising to release the transcript of a controversial call he had with Volodymyr Zelenskiy, the Ukrainian president.

But it was not enough. Ms Pelosi said: “The president must be held accountable. No one is above the law.”

Nancy Pelosi making her historic announcement Credit: REX More

She argued that Mr Trump’s alleged behaviour in the Ukraine scandal amounted to a “betrayal of his oath of office, betrayal of our national security and betrayal of the integrity of our elections”.

"Therefore, today, I am announcing the House of Representatives is moving forward with an official impeachment inquiry."

Mrs Pelosi added: "The actions taken to date by the president have seriously violated the Constitution, especially when the president says 'I can do whatever I want.'

"This week the president has admitted to asking Ukraine to take actions which would benefit him politically. The president must be held accountable. No-one is above the law."

She said approval of impeachment was a "Constitutional power of the utmost gravity" but it was the "responsibility" of the House to uphold the republic.

Mr Trump hit back on Twitter within minutes of the announcement, questioning why Democrats had not waited for the release of the call transcript and declaring: “PRESIDENTIAL HARASSMENT!

PRESIDENTIAL HARASSMENT! — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) September 24, 2019

It came after momentum for impeachment steadily increased throughout Tuesday as Democrats who had previously opposed the move switched their position over the Ukraine saga.

By mid-afternoon 160 Democrat members of the House, out of a total of 235, backed impeachment, some talking about how the “dam has broken”.

Joe Biden, the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2020, joined the calls.
